trans-unit.source: Executing Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Executing Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: Executing Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Executing Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Executing Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Executing Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: Previous -- Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Previous -- Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: An *expression tree* is a data structure that represents some code.
trans-unit.target: An *expression tree* is a data structure that represents some code.

trans-unit.source: It is not compiled and executable code.
trans-unit.target: It is not compiled and executable code.

trans-unit.source: If you want to execute the .NET code that is represented by an expression tree, you must convert it into executable IL instructions.
trans-unit.target: If you want to execute the .NET code that is represented by an expression tree, you must convert it into executable IL instructions.

trans-unit.source: Lambda Expressions to Functions
trans-unit.target: Lambda Expressions to Functions

trans-unit.source: You can convert any LambdaExpression, or any type derived from LambdaExpression into executable IL.
trans-unit.target: You can convert any LambdaExpression, or any type derived from LambdaExpression into executable IL.

trans-unit.source: Other expression types cannot be directly converted into code.
trans-unit.target: Other expression types cannot be directly converted into code.

trans-unit.source: This restriction has little effect in practice.
trans-unit.target: This restriction has little effect in practice.

trans-unit.source: Lambda expressions are the only types of expressions that you would want to execute by converting to executable intermediate language (IL).
trans-unit.target: Lambda expressions are the only types of expressions that you would want to execute by converting to executable intermediate language (IL).

trans-unit.source: (Think about what it would mean to directly execute a `ConstantExpression`.
trans-unit.target: (Think about what it would mean to directly execute a `ConstantExpression`.

trans-unit.source: Would it mean anything useful?) Any expression tree that is a `LamdbaExpression`, or a type derived from `LambdaExpression` can be converted to IL.
trans-unit.target: Would it mean anything useful?) Any expression tree that is a `LamdbaExpression`, or a type derived from `LambdaExpression` can be converted to IL.

trans-unit.source: The expression type `Expression<TDelegate>` is the only concrete example in the .NET Core libraries.
trans-unit.target: The expression type `Expression<TDelegate>` is the only concrete example in the .NET Core libraries.

trans-unit.source: It's used to represent an expression that maps to any delegate type.
trans-unit.target: It's used to represent an expression that maps to any delegate type.

trans-unit.source: Because this type maps to a delegate type, .NET can examine the expression, and generate IL for an appropriate delegate that matches the signature of the lambda expression.
trans-unit.target: Because this type maps to a delegate type, .NET can examine the expression, and generate IL for an appropriate delegate that matches the signature of the lambda expression.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, this creates a simple mapping between an expression, and its corresponding delegate.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, this creates a simple mapping between an expression, and its corresponding delegate.

trans-unit.source: For example, an expression tree that is represented by `Expression<Func<int>>` would be converted to a delegate of the type `Func<int>`.
trans-unit.target: For example, an expression tree that is represented by `Expression<Func<int>>` would be converted to a delegate of the type `Func<int>`.

trans-unit.source: For a lambda expression with any return type and argument list, there exists a delegate type that is the target type for the executable code represented by that lamdba expression.
trans-unit.target: For a lambda expression with any return type and argument list, there exists a delegate type that is the target type for the executable code represented by that lamdba expression.

trans-unit.source: The `LamdbaExpression` type contains `Compile` and `CompileToMethod` members that you would use to convert an expression tree to executable code.
trans-unit.target: The `LamdbaExpression` type contains `Compile` and `CompileToMethod` members that you would use to convert an expression tree to executable code.

trans-unit.source: The `Compile` method creates a delegate.
trans-unit.target: The `Compile` method creates a delegate.

trans-unit.source: The `ConmpileToMethod` method updates a `MethodBuilder` object with the IL that represents the compiled output of the expression tree.
trans-unit.target: The `ConmpileToMethod` method updates a `MethodBuilder` object with the IL that represents the compiled output of the expression tree.

trans-unit.source: Note that `CompileToMethod` is only available on the full desktop framework, not on the .NET Core framework.
trans-unit.target: Note that `CompileToMethod` is only available on the full desktop framework, not on the .NET Core framework.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you can also provide a `DebugInfoGenerator` that will receive the symbol debugging information for the generated delegate object.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, you can also provide a `DebugInfoGenerator` that will receive the symbol debugging information for the generated delegate object.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to convert the expression tree into a delegate object, and have full debugging information about the generated delegate.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to convert the expression tree into a delegate object, and have full debugging information about the generated delegate.

trans-unit.source: You would convert an expression into a delegate using the following code:
trans-unit.target: You would convert an expression into a delegate using the following code:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the delegate type is based on the expression type.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the delegate type is based on the expression type.

trans-unit.source: You must know the return type and the argument list if you want to use the delegate object in a strongly typed manner.
trans-unit.target: You must know the return type and the argument list if you want to use the delegate object in a strongly typed manner.

trans-unit.source: The `LambdaExpression.Compile()` method returns the `Delegate` type.
trans-unit.target: The `LambdaExpression.Compile()` method returns the `Delegate` type.

trans-unit.source: You will have to cast it to the correct delegate type to have any compile-time tools check the argument list of return type.
trans-unit.target: You will have to cast it to the correct delegate type to have any compile-time tools check the argument list of return type.

trans-unit.source: Execution and Lifetimes
trans-unit.target: Execution and Lifetimes

trans-unit.source: You execute the code by invoking the delegate created when you called `LamdbaExpression.Compile()`.
trans-unit.target: You execute the code by invoking the delegate created when you called `LamdbaExpression.Compile()`.

trans-unit.source: You can see this above where `add.Compile()` returns a delegate.
trans-unit.target: You can see this above where `add.Compile()` returns a delegate.

trans-unit.source: Invoking that delegate, by calling `func()` executes the code.
trans-unit.target: Invoking that delegate, by calling `func()` executes the code.

trans-unit.source: That delegate represents the code in the expression tree.
trans-unit.target: That delegate represents the code in the expression tree.

trans-unit.source: You can retain the handle to that delegate and invoke it later.
trans-unit.target: You can retain the handle to that delegate and invoke it later.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to compile the expression tree each time you want to execute the code it represents.
trans-unit.target: You don't need to compile the expression tree each time you want to execute the code it represents.

trans-unit.source: (Remember that expression trees are immutable, and compiling the same expression tree later will create a delegate that executes the same code.)
trans-unit.target: (Remember that expression trees are immutable, and compiling the same expression tree later will create a delegate that executes the same code.)

trans-unit.source: I will caution you against trying to create any more sophisticated caching mechanisms to increase performance by avoiding unnecessary compile calls.
trans-unit.target: I will caution you against trying to create any more sophisticated caching mechanisms to increase performance by avoiding unnecessary compile calls.

trans-unit.source: Comparing two arbitrary expression trees to determine if they represent the same algorithm will also be time consuming to execute.
trans-unit.target: Comparing two arbitrary expression trees to determine if they represent the same algorithm will also be time consuming to execute.

trans-unit.source: You'll likely find that the compute time you save avoiding any extra calls to `LambdaExpression.Compile()` will be more than consumed by the time executing code that determines of two different expression trees result in the same executable code.
trans-unit.target: You'll likely find that the compute time you save avoiding any extra calls to `LambdaExpression.Compile()` will be more than consumed by the time executing code that determines of two different expression trees result in the same executable code.

trans-unit.source: Caveats
trans-unit.target: Caveats

trans-unit.source: Compiling a lambda expression to a delegate and invoking that delegate is one of the simplest operations you can perform with an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: Compiling a lambda expression to a delegate and invoking that delegate is one of the simplest operations you can perform with an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: However, even with this simple operation, there are caveats you must be aware of.
trans-unit.target: However, even with this simple operation, there are caveats you must be aware of.

trans-unit.source: Lambda Expressions create closures over any local variables that are referenced in the expression.
trans-unit.target: Lambda Expressions create closures over any local variables that are referenced in the expression.

trans-unit.source: You must guarantee that any variables that would be part of the delegate are usable at the location where you call `Compile`, and when you execute the resulting delegate.
trans-unit.target: You must guarantee that any variables that would be part of the delegate are usable at the location where you call `Compile`, and when you execute the resulting delegate.

trans-unit.source: In general, the compiler will ensure that this is true.
trans-unit.target: In general, the compiler will ensure that this is true.

trans-unit.source: However, if your expression accesses a variable that implements `IDisposable`, it's possible that your code might dispose of the object while it is still held by the expression tree.
trans-unit.target: However, if your expression accesses a variable that implements `IDisposable`, it's possible that your code might dispose of the object while it is still held by the expression tree.

trans-unit.source: For example, this code works fine, because `int` does not implement `IDisposable`:
trans-unit.target: For example, this code works fine, because `int` does not implement `IDisposable`:

trans-unit.source: The delegate has captured a reference to the local variable `constant`.
trans-unit.target: The delegate has captured a reference to the local variable `constant`.

trans-unit.source: That variable is accessed at any time later, when the function returned by `CreateBoundFunc` executes.
trans-unit.target: That variable is accessed at any time later, when the function returned by `CreateBoundFunc` executes.

trans-unit.source: However, consider this (rather contrived) class that implements `IDisposable`:
trans-unit.target: However, consider this (rather contrived) class that implements `IDisposable`:

trans-unit.source: If you use it in an expression as shown below, you'll get an `ObjectDisposedException` when you execute the code referenced by the `Resource.Argument` property:
trans-unit.target: If you use it in an expression as shown below, you'll get an `ObjectDisposedException` when you execute the code referenced by the `Resource.Argument` property:

trans-unit.source: The delegate returned from this method has closed over the `constant` object, which has been disposed of.
trans-unit.target: The delegate returned from this method has closed over the `constant` object, which has been disposed of.

trans-unit.source: (It's been disposed, because it was declared in a `using` statement.)
trans-unit.target: (It's been disposed, because it was declared in a `using` statement.)

trans-unit.source: Now, when you execute the delegate returned from this method, you'll have a `ObjecctDisposedException` thrown at the point of execution.
trans-unit.target: Now, when you execute the delegate returned from this method, you'll have a `ObjecctDisposedException` thrown at the point of execution.

trans-unit.source: It does seem strange to have a runtime error representing a compile-time construct, but that's the world we enter when we work with expression trees.
trans-unit.target: It does seem strange to have a runtime error representing a compile-time construct, but that's the world we enter when we work with expression trees.

trans-unit.source: There are a lot of permutations of this problem, so it's hard to offer general guidance to avoid it.
trans-unit.target: There are a lot of permutations of this problem, so it's hard to offer general guidance to avoid it.

trans-unit.source: Be careful about accessing local variables when defining expressions, and be careful about accessing state in the current object (represented by `this`) when creating an expression tree that can be returned by a public API.
trans-unit.target: Be careful about accessing local variables when defining expressions, and be careful about accessing state in the current object (represented by `this`) when creating an expression tree that can be returned by a public API.

trans-unit.source: The code in your expression may reference methods or properties in other assemblies.
trans-unit.target: The code in your expression may reference methods or properties in other assemblies.

trans-unit.source: That assembly must be accessible when the expression is defined, and when it is compiled, and when the resulting delegate is invoked.
trans-unit.target: That assembly must be accessible when the expression is defined, and when it is compiled, and when the resulting delegate is invoked.

trans-unit.source: You'll be met with a `ReferencedAssemblyNotFoundException` in cases where it is not present.
trans-unit.target: You'll be met with a `ReferencedAssemblyNotFoundException` in cases where it is not present.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: Expression Trees that represent lambda expressions can be compiled to create a delegate that you can execute.
trans-unit.target: Expression Trees that represent lambda expressions can be compiled to create a delegate that you can execute.

trans-unit.source: This provides one mechanism to execute the code represented by an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: This provides one mechanism to execute the code represented by an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: The Expression Tree does represent the code that would execute for any given construct you create.
trans-unit.target: The Expression Tree does represent the code that would execute for any given construct you create.

trans-unit.source: As long as the environment where you compile and execute the code matches the environment where you create the expression, everything works as expected.
trans-unit.target: As long as the environment where you compile and execute the code matches the environment where you create the expression, everything works as expected.

trans-unit.source: When that doesn't happen, the errors are very predictable, and they will be caught in your first tests of any code using the expression trees.
trans-unit.target: When that doesn't happen, the errors are very predictable, and they will be caught in your first tests of any code using the expression trees.
